<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q66')" data-correct-answer="C">
<strong style="display: block;">
You hold a stock with **expected return 14%** and **volatility 28%**.  
The risk-free rate is 3% and the market portfolio has **expected return 11%** and **volatility 16%**.  
According to the **Capital Market Line (CML)**, what is the **minimum volatility** you can achieve while targeting the **same 14% expected return** as the stock?  
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q66" value="A"> A. 18.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q66" value="B"> B. 20.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q66" value="C"> C. 22.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q66" value="D"> D. 24.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q66" value="E"> E. 28.0%</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q66" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C. On the CML, any target return is achieved with the **minimum variance** by combining the risk-free asset and the **market (tangency) portfolio**:
\(E[R]=r_f + x\,(E[R_m]-r_f)\).
For 14%: \(x=\dfrac{0.14-0.03}{0.11-0.03}=1.375\).
This means weights \(w_m=137.5\%\) and \(w_{rf}=1-x=-37.5\%\) (borrow 37.5% at \(r_f\)).
The volatility on the CML scales linearly with \(x\):
\(\sigma = x\,\sigma_m = 1.375\times 16\% = 22\%\).
So you can reach **14%** with only **22%** volatility—dominating the individual stock at **28%**.
<em>Note:</em> This uses the standard CML assumptions (frictionless borrowing/lending at \(r_f\)); with borrowing constraints, the minimum σ could be higher.
</div>

:::
